data.title: .gitignored files removed by "Clean All" action

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1607 / build 14393.82)

If you select "Clean All" while you have changes staged, then a .gitignored `.vscode/launch.json` file will be unexpectedly removed. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an empty folder
2. Open the folder in VS Code
3. Switch to the git tab
4. Initialize the git repository
5. Hit F5
6. Select "Node.js" to create a launch.json
7. Create a .gitignore file with the contents `.vscode/launch.json`
8. Stage the .gitignore file
9. Create a new file `foo.js`
10. Select "clean all" from the Changes section of the Git tab
11. Confirm the dialog

Expected:
- `foo.js` is removed
- `.vscode/launch.json` still exists

Actual:
- `foo.js` is removed
- `.vscode/launch.json` is removed

This is super annoying, because my launch.json contains secret values in the environment settings, so I can't check it in.

data.title: Align more keybindings with Mac conventions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I know I can override my keybindings, but this bug is about sensible defaults.

Take the simple <kbd>Cmd+{</kbd>. iTerm2 is sitting beside vscode, and I <kbd>Cmd+Tab</kbd> to it and use this keybinding. When I <kbd>Cmd+Tab</kbd> back to vscode, this key combination suddenly does folding. I'm supposed to use <kbd>Ctrl+$digit</kbd> to switch between tabs here. And <kbd>Cmd+$digit</kbd> means something else entirely! This is unacceptable.

I come from the Emacs world, so I'm used to hitting <kbd>Ctrl+g</kbd> to cancel any operation (equivalent to vscode's <kbd>Esc</kbd>). In vscode, this key combination is goto-line! goto-lie is a fairly common operation, so this is fine; I can choose to either re-train my muscle memory or override.

I come from the Atom world as well, and <kbd>Cmd+b</kbd> switches buffers. This in itself isn't so bad, but the alternative chosen for <kbd>Cmd+b</kbd> is terrible! Why is hiding the left-pane such a common operation that we need to provide a toplevel keybinding for it? In the absence of a better suggestion, we can alias it to <kbd>Cmd+p</kbd>.

<kbd>Cmd++</kbd> being replaced with <kbd>Cmd+=</kbd> is an unnecessary source of confusion.

data.title: Test IME
data.body:
"Known" IME tests (collected from various bugs) are available at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/IME-Test
Please feel free to improve the IME tests wiki entry, especially if you are on mac or on linux. Perhaps the windows tests provide inspiration on how IME should work on mac/linux.
- [x] VSCode Windows - complexity 2 **@roblourens**
- [x] VScode Mac - complexity 2 **@jrieken**
- [x] VSCode Linux - complexity 4 (I understand it is difficult to add an input method to Linux?) **@aeschli**
- [x] monaco-editor Windows Edge - complexity 2 **@roblourens**
- [x] monaco-editor Windows IE11 - complexity 2 **@roblourens**
- [x] monaco-editor Any OS Chrome 52 - complexity 2 **@jrieken**
- [x] monaco-editor Any OS Firefox 48 - complexity 2  **@jrieken**

To test VSCode simply open VSCode and follow the very detailed steps in the wiki page. If you have to test on Windows, go through the `[Windows]` tests, etc.

To test monaco-editor:
- clone the monaco-editor repository next to vscode, such that they are siblings. 
- do `npm install` in the monaco-editor repository.
- run `gulp watch` in the vscode repository.
- open `monaco-editor/test/index.html` in the browser you are assigned (file protocol is OK)
- load the editor from `dev` such that it loads from the vscode repo:
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/18070656/9d9c91de-6e4f-11e6-8335-7084d796e4d8.png)
- your url should look like `file:///C:/Alex/src/monaco-editor/test/index.html?editor=dev#Y___DefaultJS` <-- notice the `editor=dev` part.
- now you can begin the IME test

data.title: Test: Should allow adjusting font weight
data.body:
Test for #381 (came in via PR #10515)
- [x] Any OS **dbaeumer**

Complexity 1

Adds two new settings `editor.fontWeight` and `terminal.integrated.fontWeight`. If `terminal.integrated.fontWeight` is missing, `editor.fontWeight` will be picked up by the terminal.

Please check that you can change the editor's and the terminal's font weight.

data.title: Test: Allow workspaceContains to specify directories
data.body:
Test for #8295 (came in via PR #9394)
- [x] Any OS **dbaeumer**

Complexity 2

Test that if you have an extension with an activation event `workspaceContains:filename` you can now use a top level workspace folder name besides a file name (file names worked before).

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/activation-events#_activationeventsworkspacecontains

data.title: Test: Option to wrap at specified column only when window is larger than the specified number of columns
data.body:
Test for #1490 (came in via PR #7029)
- [x] Any OS **gregvanl**

Complexity 1

There is a new setting `editor.wordWrap` that interacts with `editor.wrappingColumn`:

| wrappingColumn | wordWrap | Effect | New? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | false | Viewport Wrapping. | No |
| -1 | false | No Wrapping. | No |
| 80 | false | Wraps at 80 columns. | No |
| 0 | true | Viewport Wrapping. | No |
| -1 | true | No Wrapping. | No |
| 80 | true | If viewport > 80 cols Wrap at 80 columns; else Viewport Wrapping. | Yes |

Please check that `editor.wrappingColumn` works as before when `editor.wordWrap` is false.
Please check that if `editor.wrappingColumn > 0` and `editor.wordWrap` is true, the view wraps at `min(editor.wrappingColumn, viewportColumnWidth)`.

data.title: Test: Enable emmet for other languages #9500
data.body:
Test for #9500
- [x] Windows and Mac **@ramya-rao-a**, **@waderyan**
- [x] Any OS **@aeschli**

Complexity 1

You can enable emmet for other languages both as a user and as a language contributor.
## Enable emmet for a new language as a user.

As a user you can define an emmet syntax profile and associate an emmet supported profile to a language. For a list of supported emmet profiles see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9500#issuecomment-242221652. For example to associate `java` with the `html` syntax profile you can define the setting:

``` json
{
  "emmet.syntaxProfiles": {
    "java": "html"
  }
}
```
- Verify that emmet abbreviations are expanded inside an java file using the html profile.
## Enable emmet as a language provider

As a language provider you can associate your language with an emmet syntax profile by adding an emmet supported profile in the scope name of the grammar  (textmate [language grammar](https://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars)). For example, define the scope of you

``` json
        "grammars": [
            {
                "language": "foo",
                "scopeName": "text.html.foo"
            }
        ]
```

Define a language foo as shown above. 
- Verify that in file of type foo you emmet abbreviations using the html support.
- Verify that you get emmet abbreviations independent of where `html` appears in the scope name.

data.body: I know F can start find in files, but is there a short cut can take the current word under cursor and start search, rather than select, copy, find in files, paste and enter?

data.title: Test: True integrated terminal keybinding support
data.body:
Test #7269
- [x] Mac **@gregvanl**
- [x] Windows **@gregvanl**
- [x] Linux **@octref**

---

The new setting `terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell` was added that specifies a list of commands whose keybindings will not be processed by the shell first and instead propogate up to the vscode keybinding handler. For example the default is:

``` json
  "terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell": [
      "editor.action.toggleTabFocusMode",
      "workbench.action.quickOpen",
      "workbench.action.showCommands",
      "workbench.action.terminal.copySelection",
      "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
      "workbench.action.terminal.focusNext",
      "workbench.action.terminal.focusPrevious",
      "workbench.action.terminal.kill",
      "workbench.action.terminal.new",
      "workbench.action.terminal.paste",
      "workbench.action.terminal.runSelectedText",
      "workbench.action.terminal.scrollDown",
      "workbench.action.terminal.scrollUp",
      "workbench.action.terminal.toggleTerminal"
  ]
```

This ensures that all terminal commands are handled to the keybinding handler in addition to accessibility tab focus mode, quick open and the command palette.

Some things to test:
- Whether it works as expected
- Whether the default list of commands makes sense, think whether the default keybindings for these commands would conflict with command terminal programs
- Whether any more commands should be added to the default list of commands

data.title: images with relative paths in extension's README.md aren't shown in the extension manager
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have an extension which has a README with images with relative path, e.g. https://raw.githubusercontent.com/vshaxe/vshaxe/master/README.md
2. Open extension manager, click on that extension - images aren't shown:

![](http://i.imgur.com/iqmry3h.png)

Note that those images are shown in Marketplace, on Github and when using VSCode's Markdown Preview feature.

`cmd.exe`: ctrl+home/end

data.title: Test: Integrated terminal scroll bar
data.body:
Test for #10320
- [x] Windows **@ramya-rao-a**
- [x] Linux **@rebornix**
- [x] Mac **@kieferrm**

---

A scroll bar was added to the integrated terminal, try to break it! Some suggestions:
- Scroll one page at a time (ctrl+shift+pg up/down)
- Scroll one line at a time (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/7c734490c7ae54a217f7390a2a888f94ef3653e0, #10302)
- Scroll using mouse wheel/trackpad, fiddle with OS settings to make it scroll at different speeds (you can configure some OS' to scroll by pixel, line or page)
- Use different shells
- Enter and exit applications such as `vim` and make sure it still works

data.title: Test: Integrated terminal API
data.body:
Test for #9957
- [x] Windows **@octref**
- [x] Linux **@rebornix**
- [x] Mac **@ramya-rao-a**

---

An API for the integrated terminal was added. See [`window.createTerminal`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/ae7e12fda1f81a7ecd7579bef7f140f2459ee307/src/vs/vscode.d.ts#L3497) and [`vscode.Terminal`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/ae7e12fda1f81a7ecd7579bef7f140f2459ee307/src/vs/vscode.d.ts#L2995). To test this please make sure the API does what it claims and that it fits your expectations and is useful.

Instructions for testing against latest API here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11111#issuecomment-243132501

Sample API implementation here: https://github.com/Tyriar/vscode-terminal-api-example

data.title: Test file icons themes (user experience)
data.body:
- [x] OSX  **@bpasero**
- [x] Linux **@isidorn**
- [x] Windows **@dbaeumer**

Test the new file icon theme from a user perspective
- Install the Seti icon theme from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-theme-seti

User experience:
- Test the icon theme picker at `File > Preferences > File Icon Theme`
  - test that you see a preview while browsing through the themes, but only in the current window
- Test the 'Icon Theme' command (F1)
- test that when you select a theme it is applied to all windows
- test that the selected icon theme is persisted over restarts  
- test the Standard and Seti theme in light, dark and high contrast theme
  - verify that the Standard theme shows icons for open and closed folder as well as a single icon for files
  - verify that the Seti theme does not show folder icons, but many different icons for various file types.
- verify that the rename dialog in the file explorer is correctly positioned

data.title: Test Scrolling and Folding API commands
data.body:
Test for #9609 and #9786
- [x] Any OS **@weinand**

Complexity 4
## Set up
- Clone the repository [VS Code Extension Samples](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples)
- Go to the folder **vim-sample** and do npm install
- Open VS Code on **vim-sample**
- Run the extension using Launch Extension. 

This will run Vim sample extension and is referred as Vim editor from here after. Verify following scenarios on this. 
## Good to know
- Vim editor has basically 3 modes: `Normal`, `Visual`, `Edit`.
### Mode change
- Press `i` for edit mode when in normal or visual mode.
- Press `esc` for normal node when in edit mode.
- Press `v` for visual mode when in normal mode.
### Line vs wrapped line

A line is a complete line that can consists of one or more wrapped lines in the screen.

**Note**: All of these scenarios have to be tested in **non-edit mode**
**Note**: When window scrolls downwards, cursor/lines move upwards and vice-versa
### Test up and down scrolling
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>e</kbd> Scroll window 1 line downwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>e</kbd> Scroll window N lines downwards
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>d</kbd> Scroll half window lines downwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>d</kbd> Scroll N half window lines downwards 
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>f</kbd> Scroll one window lines downwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>f</kbd> Scroll N window lines downwards
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>y</kbd> Scroll window 1 line upwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>y</kbd> Scroll window N lines upwards
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>u</kbd> Scroll half window lines upwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>u</kbd> Scroll N half window lines upwards
- <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>b</kbd> Scroll one window lines upwards
-  <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>b</kbd> Scroll N window lines upwards

Make sure during scrolling, cursor is always revealed in the current window.
### Test revealing current line
- <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>t</kbd> Reveals current line at top of window
- <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>z</kbd> Reveals current line at center of window
- <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>b</kbd> Reveals current line at bottom of window
### Test folding / unfolding
- <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>c</kbd> Close one fold under the cursor.
-  <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>c</kbd> Close N folds deep under the cursor.
- <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>o</kbd> Open one fold under the cursor.
-  <kbd>z</kbd> + <kbd>o</kbd> Open N folds deep under the cursor.
